page.title: 13THE CITADEL
page.content: This{fortification}was built in the 1660s and is not only one of Plymouth's most historic{buildings}but also one of the finest remaining 17C forts in the country. From its position on the eastern end of the Hoe,it could easily defend the entrance to the Cattewater and Sutton Pool,then the major berthing areas of the King's Navy.Its{ramparts are 70ft. thick and in places 60 ft. high.Although if never enjoyed active fighting,it did have 165 guns.Those that remain ,mostly 19C are ornamental. Since the turn of the century the Citadel has been the home of the{Royal {Artillery,}and the 29 Commando unit now inhabits its imposing buildings which include the extremely pretty {St.Catherine's chapel,}which is open to the publi.
